reviews.review: Gripping story and the most realistic war movie Ive ever seen. Gives a new profound level of respect for our men and women service members.
This was exceptional. Loved everything about it. One of the best movies I’ve seen in a long long time. Well done

This is a super intense movie. Watching this made me only think about how our armed forces deal with situations like these and function as normal humans after they enter civilian life. You can totally understand where PTSD originates from. The acting is great, it is gut wrenching and I had to hold myself back from tears. It just brought that out in me, even though it is not a tearjerker in any way or form. Great filmmaking about what it is like to be on the edge of a life or death situation at any second.
Such a good movie, so raw, so real, so heartbreaking. My heart was beating so hard and my entire body was sweating. It really encapsulates what these soldiers go through.
Horrible movie, how it has a 93 is beyond me. They were just screaming and crying the whole movie annoying felt like throwing my phone against the wall. Don't waste your time.

This was very intense look into warfare.
Intense movie from start to finish.

One of the worst movies i have ever seen. watching paint dry is more entertaining.
It was worth a watch.

Navy Seals stuck in a house in Iraq surrounded by about 20 insurgents. No idea what their mission is and the only time they leave the house in when they exit in a Bradley. The wife fell asleep and I wish I had joined her.

They could have made the movie watchable while also showing how terrible war is. There’s really no clear objective, what they’re doing there, then they get blown up. It sucks, that’s an awful situation, but they also made a movie about it. Some dialogue would have helped

Not the war movie that pumps you up but one that is needed more than ever. I can’t forget how perfect the sound design was along with the visual changes added into the camera work while it follows each character to make you forget you’re in a theater and give you anxiety and stress like you’re part of the squad.
Extremely engrossing, realistic, and heart-wrenching. Very accurate in terms of how military runs/interacts. Everyone should be required to watch this movie to see what war really is!

I went in expecting Warfare to be just another run-of-the-mill war movie. But by the time it ended, I found myself deeply absorbed, reflecting on the harsh realities of war. Alex Garland and Ray Mendoza have masterfully directed this film, building tension frame by frame. The suspense feels natural and grounded, while the depiction of gore and violence captures the brutal realism of combat more authentically than most films dare to show. By the one-hour mark, you're fully immersed — right there on the battlefield alongside the American soldiers, trying to make sense of the chaos and the instinct to survive. Will Poulter and Cosmo Jarvis deliver exceptional performances, breathing life into their characters with raw intensity. Overall, this is a must-watch for fans of the war genre — and an outstanding film by any standard
Best war movie to date in my mind chaotic and extremely fast paced. Little to no exposition and beautifully shot.
An honest and visceral depiction of modern combat that leaves a lasting impact.
Reminded me of The Outpost, but under a macro lens; visceral PTSD of a film. Outstanding.
"Warfare" is exactly what it is...warfare.

I was deployed to Afghanistan in 2005. People used to ask if I could watch war movies. They wanted to know if it would 'bring me back' to combat, as if I didn't realize there's a difference between a movie and the real thing. This movie did. This, for me, was a very realistic portrayal of a day in the life. I had tears in my eyes in that theater. For all of you "Patriots," and people who wish to thank military members for their service, you owe it to yourself to get a very small glimpse of what you're thanking them for. Don't expect a Hollywood happy ending in where a soldier's to be rejoined back home with loved ones. The Hurt Locker kind of reminded me of this. The war isn't over just because you've won/lost the battle.
Wow, this film is a hard watch when it kicks off. Story was great, definitely worth going to see.

Great movie. Nothing like other war movies where there is just nonsense gunfire. Every step is calculated, which I really appreciate. The radio communication, movement, and the soldiers' temperament seem very realistic. There are a lot of surprises and difficulties you wouldn't account for if you never get to watch it. Highly recommend to anyone.

An interesting movie, as it is based on a true war experience that the director had during the Iraq War. I think what makes the movie great is the phenomenal sound design and the grounded, realistic representation of war. There is no glorification of the soldiers or the war — it is dirty, frightening, and downright horrific. Most of the story revolves entirely around one house, as tension mounts throughout the film. The only problem is that there is no real understanding or exploration of any of the characters. However, I think that's fine, because the film is more about the horror of war than anything else.

I guess i was thankful it was a realistic reenactment but it was anticlimactic. Didn’t really get attached or relate to any characters. And just when i felt like the movie was starting it ended. It didn’t feel like a long movie bc i was anticipating some action to happen. But it just seemed like it abruptly ended.

This is an incredible story of American Military in this war impacted area fighting for their lives. It’s not sugarcoated and is quite realistic of the ghastly aspects of fighting with gunfire, explosives and showing force. Production, acting and screen visualizations are phenomenal. I’m reminded of films like Black Hawk Down and the Hurtlocker dealing with intense military events. All the respect and regard to the US Military and allies that have protected freedom.

The kind of movie that depicts the pointlessness of war almost to a fault. Direction and acting are excellent but the storyline is non existent, making it something that really won't stand up to repeat viewing.
Best of the modern war movies. Period. Full stop.

How do you leave a One Star review for a movie where our troops fought and returned injured?? It's tough. I bought this movie for $20 when it became available at home and I really wanted to like it. American Sniper, Lone Survivor, Blackhawk Down, so many amazing war movies. This one simply had no point. It was as if they took one incident where a soldier got seriously injured and tried to make it the story of the century. At one point, they tried to minimize one soldier's injuries for another, and then made that lesser injured soldier look like he was just looking to get morphine. Another scene a guy fell in battle and you think, "was he hit, is he mentally messed up..." only to have him say "I tripped" when his partner asked if he was hit. Overall, you are left with an anticlimactic feeling like the storyline was weak. Soldiers hold up in a home, they are under fire, a few get injured, they evacuate the house...the end. Isn't that every soldier's battle story. Brave men and they deserve our eternal respect, but this wasn't movie material.

I don’t really understand how people keep saying this is some sort of gratuitous war movie. Nothing about it really feels gratuitous. It’s literally a story about an operation gone wrong during the Iraq War. I would not say it’s the best war movie I’ve seen but it isn’t the worst. The acting is pretty good and believable. The tone of the movie is intense. The sound design and mixing is fantastic. If you go into this expecting some sort of action film like Saving Private Ryan or Enemy at the Gates, you will be severely disappointed.
I felt like the director didn't want me to feel a connection with the characters, but more of what a war really is and let me tell you, that movie was insane. highly recommend.

This movie was almost good. But almost doesn't count except in hand grenades, horse shoes, and nuclear weapons. First off let me pre-face this review by saying that some of the things I think sucked and were stupid very well may have happened IRL, and may have just been military/government logic at it's finest, as opposed to the filmmakers being idiots. But I kind of doubt it. I do an also want to start with the positives. The costumes were decent, the acting was decent, the trailer looked awesome, and there was 1 brief scene were 2 SEALs were on a roof top exchanging fire with some bad guys where it looked like they actually knew what they were doing. But there's just a few things that killed all of that for me though. First off, these guys are supposedly Navy SEALs, yet in the movie they were portrayed as a bunch of awkward amateurs. Forgetting where they put their equipment repeatedly, getting shell shocked and flabbergasted anytime anything happens, messing up simple tasks. Not what I've been lead to believe SEALs are like from all the documentaries I've watched about them. Next, when it starts hitting the fan, two of their own are injured and the filmmakers spent what felt like 20 minutes focusing on nothing but these 2 injured individuals screaming, and their teammates not having a clue what to do to help them (again, SEALs?). Next up, after an IED attack out on the street, 3 SEALs go to retrieve some "gear" they left behind on said street. Presumably so that the bad guys don't get their "gear"? The 3 SEALs go out into the street shooting and covering each other to retrieve the gear in question. Which is a sledgehammer. Really? 3 SEALs risked their lives under heavy fire to run out into the street and grab a hammer? Not a grenade launcher, rifle, or bag of C4, but a hammer? Then, a few minutes later 2 Bradleys roll up to extract them in the exact spot the sledgehammer was laying, the SEALS all pour out and set up a perimeter around the Bradleys while the others load the wounded. Firstly, couldn't they have just grabbed the "gear" then? Second, the Bradleys, which are taking lots of small arms fire from all directions, don't shoot back. The SEALs are shooting, but not the Bradleys. Again, could be some military protocol I'm unaware of? Not allowed to shoot at infantry with a Bradley gun? But in a minute you'll see that go out the window. They load up the wounded, and some of the SEALs also get in the Bradleys. The Bradleys then leave, and the rest of the SEALs go back in the house. Where they continue to freak out and act confused. The bad guys are on the roof, so they call for the Bradleys to shoot the top floor of the house. The Bradleys come screeching around the corner and start shooting the roof. But wait, are these the same Bradleys that were just there? If so... why did they leave, drive a way, but then.... came back? And this time shooting. Or are these a second set of Bradleys? Nothing was said in the movie at all about a second set of Bradleys, making it look as though the same Bradleys that showed up a minute ago just went for a joy ride around the block with the wounded, then came back to exfil the rest of the SEALs which would've been done the first time. The Bradleys light up the roof, as well as all the other buildings around. And somehow they don't show a single bad guy getting hit, in fact, I realized I don't think they showed a single bad guy get hit the entire movie? A fair bit of shooting occurred on part of the SEALs and Bradleys (finally), but they didn't show a single enemy casualty. Hmm. A fighter jet does a super low fly-by for a "show of force" that kicks up a metric crap ton of dust into the air, the guys run out into the street to finally pile into the Bradleys to get away and 99% of the dust is instantly gone. They get in the Bradleys, the door shuts, and it's end of movie. I was psyched for this movie. But it left me feeling embarrassed for whoever made it, or worse if that's how these guys actually handled themselves in this situation, for them (but I doubt it). It was almost good. But wasn't.

Fantastic movie. It was raw in every right way. The gunplay was great and the sound design was amazing. Highly recommend this for any gun or war geek. It's not Saving Private Ryan, but it's just as good.

Warfare, directed by Alex Garland and Ray Mendoza, is a visceral masterpiece that redefines the war film genre with its unflinching commitment to realism. Set during a 2006 Navy SEAL mission in Ramadi, Iraq, the film immerses viewers in the chaos of combat, drawing solely from the memories of Mendoza, a former SEAL, and his comrades. This raw, documentary-like approach strips away Hollywood clichés—no heroic speeches, no contrived drama—just the stark, unrelenting reality of war. The film’s technical prowess is staggering. Glenn Freemantle’s sound design is a character in itself, capturing the cacophony of gunfire, radio chatter, and deafening explosions with bone-rattling precision. David J. Thompson’s cinematography, with its claustrophobic close-ups and fluid handheld shots, plunges audiences into the heart of the battle, making every moment feel immediate and suffocating. The real-time narrative, unfolding over 95 minutes, mirrors the soldiers’ disorientation and dread, while graphic depictions of wounds and casualties refuse to sanitize the carnage. The ensemble cast, including Will Poulter, Joseph Quinn, and D’Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai as Mendoza’s stand-in, delivers understated yet powerful performances, embodying the camaraderie and fear of young soldiers without romanticizing their roles. By focusing on the American perspective while subtly highlighting the plight of Iraqi civilians, Warfare avoids jingoism, letting the futility of conflict speak for itself. This is not entertainment—it’s a harrowing, unforgettable experience that honors the soldier’s reality and challenges viewers to confront war’s brutal truth.
Kind of a low budget film shot in only one location. The story needs to stay with those that experienced this fight. It doesn't belong to the general public.

Very intense and gruesome, even though it mostly takes place in one setting. Characters are a little bit underdeveloped but that’s fine considering the story taking place.

From purely an entertainment perspective, which is always my benchmark, it squeaks by. That is, I watched to the end with some background misgivings about how I was using my time. A Modern Portrait of War’s Brutality The Harsh Reality of War is an unflinching and visceral depiction of conflict, raw, relentless, and deeply human. Anchored by a brilliant cast, each performance carries weight and authenticity, pulling you into the trenches and refusing to let go. It captures the terror, chaos, and brotherhood of war with haunting precision, evoking the same emotional gravity as Band of Brothers, but through a distinctly modern lens. I haven't seen anything quite like it in some time. An unforgettable experience that doesn't just depict war, but makes you feel it.

10 out of 5! AMAZING! One of the most gripping and authentic portrayals of modern combat I’ve ever seen. As a veteran who served overseas, I can say with full confidence that Warfare is in a league of its own. This isn’t just another war movie, it’s a full-throttle, boots-on-the-ground experience that captures the reality of the Global War on Terror with unmatched intensity and precision. The cinematography is raw and immersive, the sound design punches with every round fired, and the attention to detail is impeccable. From tactics and comms to the emotional toll and split-second decisions, Warfare nails it. What sets this film apart is its focus on the elite Navy SEALs, the frogmen, and what they endured in silence and shadow. The pacing is relentless. From the moment the first shots are fired, you’re locked in. No fluff. Just pure, unfiltered warfare. This is as close as it gets to the real thing without being there. A masterpiece for veterans, patriots, and anyone who wants to understand what sacrifice and brotherhood truly look like on the battlefield.
The film was excellent; the absence of a persistent background music was a particularly strong point.
Raw. Graphic. Loud. Shows war in its pure colors. Good watch

Uma experiência cinematográfica concisa e impactante que nos transporta direto para o campo de batalha onde podemos não só assistir aos erros e aos acertos cometidos, mas também podemos sentir a agonia, a tensão e o medo crescendo. Dona de uma maquiagem e efeitos práticos impecáveis é uma obra que executa muito bem seu trabalho de mostrar o que foi vivido naquele dia e por aqueles que lá estiveram.

Warfare (2025) is a gritty, no-frills depiction of a 2006 Navy SEAL mission in Iraq. Directed by Ray Mendoza, a former SEAL, the film immerses viewers in the chaotic, unpredictable nature of combat, without the typical heroism or glory. The actors, led by D'Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai, deliver authentic, grounded performances that bring the realism of war to life. With intense sound design and a focus on tactical survival over drama, Warfare offers a brutal, unflinching look at what it means to fight and survive in a hostile environment. A must-see for those looking for an honest portrayal of modern warfare.

The film isn't one where you see the "good guys" mowing down in the seas of enemies. The film is nuanced and shows the ebb and flow in the reality of modern warfare. It emphasizes the team dynamic, whole balancing the impact the they have on direct environment they are in. I was a turret gunner and did QRF and served in OIF2 and appreciate the attention to detail in costuming, atmosphere, sound design, and just the general aspects of the team dynamic.

This isn't entertainment. It's immersion. Stripped bare of conventional character arcs and the need for audience allegiance, this cinematic experience delivers an unvarnished, visceral confrontation with the brutal human reality of conflict, demanding only that you witness.
The sound of warfare is what you’ll remember.

War movies are my thing. But have to disagree with other reviewers that this is one of the best war movies made. Not even in the top 10 for me. This was such an intense experience. Well done, and not for the light of heart. Represented warfare in such a personal fashion that it’s a wonder all people don’t freeze during battle. Giving into the narrative gives you a feeling as if you’re in the thick of the battle. It captures why people walk away PTSD after a war is over. Perhaps the strongest visual was the end of the film where the indigenous population are stuck with the aftermath of a political agenda.

I must admit, it’s hard to understand how this film has received such high praise. The storyline feels extremely limited, revolving almost entirely around a single wartime event, without any real setup or satisfying resolution. To its credit, the film does capture the adrenaline, urgency, and chaos of combat — there’s undeniable technical merit in that. However, it lacks narrative depth, character development, and a structure that goes beyond mere immersion in a single moment. By the end, it felt like I had watched a fragment rather than a complete work. I left the screening thinking: was that really it? One of the most uninspired war films I’ve seen.

A Tactical Blunder in 4K If 13 Hours and Black Hawk Down had a long-lost cousin who grew up watching too much YouTube videos, it would be Warfare. This Chinese knockoff attempts to honor battlefield heroism but ends up feeling like a military-themed group project where no one read the assignment. Let’s start with the positives: the cinematography is surprisingly solid. Explosions are crisp, drones glide like Michael Bay interns had a few Red Bulls, and there’s enough shaky cam to make you feel like you’re in the action—or possibly having a mild stroke. But that’s where the competence ends. The film pays tribute to bravery the same way a karaoke singer “pays tribute” to Whitney Houston—loud, passionate, and wildly off-key. Instead of showcasing coordinated heroics, Warfare gives us a team of soldiers who spend more time making bad tactical decisions than actually fighting. If military strategy was a game of chess, these guys are playing Hungry Hungry Hippos. The chain of command seems to be “whoever yells the loudest,” and at one point I’m fairly certain someone tried to call an airstrike using a selfie stick. All in all, Warfare tries to ride the coattails of better films but ends up tripping over its own plot holes. If you like your war movies with inexplicable slow-motion shots, and at least three scenes where someone yells “We’re surrounded!”—you might just enjoy this glorious mess. Final Verdict: Warfare is less “hoo-rah” and more “huh?”—but at least it looks good while failing

The greatest aspect about the war film Warfare, co-written and directed by former ex-Navy SEAL Ray Mendoza and "Civil War" alum Alex Garland, unfolds largely in real-time, intense and chaotic nature in urban combat, the bonds of brotherhood, and the struggle to survive against overwhelming odds. The enemy is often unseen, adding tension and realism which culminates the platoon's retreat and some members severely wounded. I will definitely praising for it's visceral and immersive depiction of modern combat, it's realistic portrayal of chaos and war, and strong performances of the cast, includes D'Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai, Will Poulter, and Cosmo Jarvis for their committed and effective roles of playing soldiers under duress. However, the story is rooted in a real mission experienced by Mendoza and his platoon, aims to honor those who served, as well as Elliott Miller, who was gravely injured during the actual events and has no memory of them.

A film that's positioned as one of the big bets of 2025, with a director who continues to prove he's one of the most interesting directors today and whose writing and directing skills remain truly powerful. It rounds out a film that isn't perfect, but doesn't need to be, as the result is a complete immersion into the horror of war in every sense. A film wonderfully directed by its co-directors and perfectly crafted in sound, it's worth watching with our full attention and dedication, because we're in the presence of one of the great war films of recent times, with all its skill in making us feel like we're in a documentary and, at times, a video game that unsettles, scares, and stresses you out, yet is satisfying.

Warfare thrusts viewers into the chaos of combat with a visceral, documentary-like intensity. Outstanding technical craftsmanship and immersive cinematography shine, yet the lack of narrative substance leaves the experience feeling cold and distant. It's a sensory onslaught — powerful but emotionally hollow.

I went into *Warfare* absolutely buzzing—massive expectations, killer ensemble cast, and Alex Garland at the helm? Count me in. And honestly, the film *delivers* on a lot: the realism is brutal, the performances hit every emotional note, and visually, it’s a gritty stunner. Garland’s writing shines, no doubt. But somewhere in the middle, it just… let go of me. Like a soldier slipping through a comrade’s grasp. I *wanted* to care more, to feel that tight-knit bond between characters that great war films nail. Instead, I felt more like a detached observer than a comrade in the trenches. Maybe I hyped it too hard in my head, but compared to the giants of the genre, this just didn’t punch hard enough. It’s a technically impressive piece, but emotionally? Left me cold. Still worth a watch—just don’t march in expecting a masterpiece. 2.5 stars.

What sets Warfare apart is its unblinking portrait of modern combat. It flatly refuses to glorify heroism – there’s no rippling muscles or winks to camera from the hunky lead. It’s a film that’s stripped of spectacle; presented as fact. It’s making the point: does geopolitical context really matter when bullets are flying and slamming past you by inches? Does the family whose house is destroyed get any explanation to justify their lives and home being ripped apart? Warfare," directed with a clear vision by Alex Garland, throws you headfirst into the brutal reality of a mission gone sideways. The film excels at immersing you in the visceral experience of combat – the deafening blasts and disorienting echoes truly place you alongside the soldiers. Ray Mendoza's story, one of survival and the unbreakable bonds of brotherhood, feels deeply personal, almost a thank you note to those who've kept him alive. While the lack of extensive backstories or a central character might leave you wanting deeper connections with individuals, this deliberate choice keeps the focus squarely on the relentless tension of survival. However, if you crave intense, expertly choreographed action sequences that leverage incredible surround sound to replicate the chaos of the frontlines, then "Warfare" is a must-see. The sound design team deserves high praise for their outstanding work, making this a compelling experience for any true cinephile.

Highly recommend this gripping and somber first person perspective on a SEAL Team's brotherhood throughout a perilous 24 hour day. I attended with my 16 y.o. son and we both 'enjoyed' the film, later discussing the moral ambiguities, character/leadership, and life-or-death decisions junior officers and enlisted are forced to make. This is the "war movie" you should see and appreciate, not out of blind patriotism but as an informed, empathetic citizen.

Warfare is an incredibly powerful and gripping film that doesn’t hold back. It’s raw, intense, and emotionally painful, portraying the brutal reality of combat with stunning clarity. The action is relentless and immersive, but what truly stands out is the film’s unflinching depiction of the dangers and psychological toll faced by soldiers on the front lines. This is not just another war movie—Warfare brings you face to face with the fear, chaos, and sacrifice that define life in battle. It’s a sobering reminder of what it means to serve, and it left me with deep respect and admiration for the armed forces who risk everything to protect our country. Highly recommended for those looking for a realistic and moving war film experience.

The message of this movie is that in war time conditions, the best laid plans can get blown to hell in a heartbeat. The film is basically in two parts - before the chaos and during the chaos. Not having ever served in an active war zone, I can only assume that Warfare portrays the conditions of such a situation accurately. And just as in the movies, Blackhawk Down and Saving Private Ryan, there are several times when you are on the edge of your seat (one in particular when you may come out of it). However, what those other films had that I think is lacking in Warfare was virtually no character development and an almost documentary like approach to the telling of the events as they unfolded. Clearly, to be in the position those men were would be nightmarish and I left the theater with even greater respect for those who have endured such experiences. And the “straight and narrow” approach to telling the story did result in one positive factor, in my opinion. The movie was only 95 minutes long.

More a cinematic experience than narrative story, writer-director Alex Garland and Iraqi-War-veteran-turned-film-technical-advisor Ray Mendoza's film provides no exposition, no character backstories, no manipulative musical score, and definitely no holding back in putting us smack in the middle of an active engagement with a platoon of Navy SEALs fighting in Ramadi, Iraq who finds themselves trapped in a building surrounded by enemy combatants. Re-constructed from Mendoza's memories and that of his unit, the incident is meticulously re-created on-screen in real time, beginning with their terrifying invasion of a local family home. Cleverly and crucially, the film takes its time with that quieter “first act” to set up a few of the characters whilst cranking up tensions as we wait for the inevitable onslaught. An ensemble of fine young up-and-comers, like Shogun's white-guy; new Johnny Storm, a Heartstopper, and both the son of Soprano and Rambo, certainly help define some of its often interchangeable and similar looking characters and lessen the confusion which can arise when hellish chaos takes over the rest of the film for a visceral attack on our senses. It's relentless and entirely edge-of-your-seat stuff which soon becomes unbearably real, exhausting to watch but also strangely moving. There's limited lip service paid to the depiction of the 'other side', but that's because it's formulated intrinsically as a subjective film only from the POV of the Western forces. Together with a remarkably affecting and tumultuous sound design, it fulfills its singular objective to give us as accurate as possible a cinematic depiction of warfare in order to make an unequivocal and powerful point about the horrifying brutality and futility of war. There's no politics, no heroics or heroes, and absolutely no glory here in an overwhelmingly intense 95mins runtime which I'm glad I only had to experience it once on-screen.

Simply the best war movie ever. I have been there, I know. Critics, again, have demonstrated their incapacity to understand a movie that has no main character and no love story. Idiots. The realism and the perfect reconstitution of facts are based on the Navy Seals experience in that exact house and city in Iraq. The filmography is breath taking. There is no extra BS to add to an episode that is sufficient to itself and illustrates the war the US brought to the Middle-East. No moral, no opinion is offered, which is refreshing. It talks for itself: US troops with engagement rules and heavy equipment facing mobile and determined "insurgents".

It's a fairly stacked cast list, from Will Poulter to Joseph Quinn to Charles Melton to Michael Gandolfini to D'Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai. No-one actually stands out individually, but I think that's entirely a good thing because it obviously isn't a story about any one person - it's about all of them.

Warfare is a bone shaking visceral film experience. It's a direct experience of war that is equally thrilling and distressing. It's a superb film, but one that might be hard to watch again. Written and directed by Alex Garland and Ray Mendoza this film reflects the real experience of Mendoza and his time as a Navy Seal in Iraq. Expressly one day, November 19, 2006. His Alpha team take over a house in Ramadi to oversee and protect a Marines operation. The film is set in real time, a span of about 90 minutes as the team wait and watch. But all hell breaks loose when they are attacked. The sound design of this film places you directly in the action. It's intense and gripping at all times. Mendoza has stated this film is a 'what film' and not a 'why film'. Which is true as I think this film replicates what it might feel like to be involved in war. The film makers have assembled a very talented young cast who are all very good. Especially Cosmo Jarvis, Joseph Quinn and D'Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai. A unique and unsettling film experience. But definitely not a relaxing one.

Planned a casual double-feature day... one I was really excited about, the other just a tag-along. To my surprise, Warfare turned out to be one of the most heartbreakingly beautiful films I’ve seen so far. It’s raw, beutiful and aching in the best way. The visual cinematography, the choreography, the pacing, the sound... pure cinematic poetry! I had chills all the way through. By the time the credits rolled, I was covered in goosebumps. Easily one of the best movies of the year. Huge thanks to Alex, Ray, and the incredible veterans for this unforgettable event.

The technical aspects of this film are amazing, with great camera work and choice of shot. This brutal depiction of war focus on a story from the memory of US military personnel. If you are seeking a narrative focused on the impacts on and tales of Iraqi civilians, you are in the wrong place. I don't necessarily think that it's a bad thing the directors, producers and writers choose to do this, coming from the direction they do, 'Warfare' highlights in real time military decision making as well as the profound damage war has on any party involved.

This was one of the most memorable experiences I’ll ever have watching a movie in a cinema theater. It’s so gritty, violent, and real that you can’t leave without feeling a sense of adrenaline. You could feel a chill amongst your fellow movie goers, like even though we were all strangers, we were all together on this journey and visceral experience. The sound was expertly executed, like you were on the battlefield with your own weapon. The IED explosion rocked me out of my seat basically. This is an experience and journey meant to be experienced in a move theater, and one that makes you truly realize the sacrifices and horrors of war these men and women make that will humble you to your core.

Warfare exceeded my expectations in nearly every regard. Its unfortunate that this film hasnt received the media attention it deserves. The film captures the essence of deployment lifelong stretches of monotony punctuated by brief, intense moments of chaos. Without giving too much away, watching Warfare felt like stepping back into the early 2000s. Its a powerful, grounded portrayal that deserves much more recognition. I felt like I was part of team, dropped into chaos of relentless battlefield. This movie, bold foray into gritty war drama, hit me like shockwave. From opening scene, shaky cam and deafening sound design plunged me into ambush in Iraq’s Anbar Province, circa 2007. It’s not just movie, it’s sensory assault that mirrors disorientation of combat. Playing as composite of real life operators, cast, led by stoic yet haunted lead, nails brotherhood and quiet intensity of elite operators. Plot doesn’t reinvent genre: high stakes mission to neutralize terrorist cell goes sideways, forcing team to navigate hostile city. But it’s execution that sets it apart. Dialogue feels ripped from actual comms, terse, tactical, human. No heroics, just desperate decisions under fire. Film’s strength is authenticity, reportedly shaped by veteran consultants. Every reload, every room clearance, feels procedural yet unpredictable. Urban combat scenes, blending drones and practical effects, are claustrophobic and brutal. Nighttime raid lit only by night vision and muzzle flashes had my heart pounding. Yet, it’s not all adrenaline. Quieter moments, like operator grappling with civilian casualty, cut deep, showing psychological toll without preaching. I left theater rattled, grateful for glimpse into world I’ll never know firsthand.

Almost all of us can only imagine the horrors of war. Last year, director Alex Garland showed us war from the perspective of journalists in CIVIL WAR, which was great. Now, he is back again, this time codirecting and cowriting with Iraq war veteran Ray Mendoza, who was his military supervisor last year. WARFARE features a platoon of soldiers in an incident of war in Iraq in 2006, namely, Mendoza’s own platoon. They have extremely talented actors including D’Pharaoh Woon-A-Tai as Ray, Will Poulter as Erik, Joseph Quinn as Sam, Charles Melton as Jake, Cosmo Jarvis as Elliot, and Michael Gandolfini as McDonald. All give top-tier performances. This is definitely one of those A24 movies that might not do well in the box office but is a one-of-a-kind experience. This is the most intense anxiety-inducing movie I’ve ever seen. It’s visceral, dirty, disorientating, and just feels real. Having no music, it relies on some of the best sound design I’ve ever heard. The gunfire is loud and everywhere. The explosions rock you to the core. This and the smooth handheld camera work makes for complete immersion. My boots were on the ground. This was made to be seen in the theaters. The filmmakers aren’t interested in the typical Hollywood format. It has no character development, no background as to what these soldiers are doing there. You get as much context as they do, relying on their radio communications and what’s going on around them. It expects you to pick up on details like the military terminologies and equipment they use. It goes through each character’s reactions as it unfolds, whether it’s becoming shellshocked, being in unimaginable pain, or just being reckless. You can be the most prepared person in the world, you still won’t know how you’ll react in a warzone. The first half has a slow build, but it’s just establishing where you are and who’ll you’re with. This is the kind of movie A24 should be supporting. No other studio would’ve touched this one. It doesn’t shy away from anything. From a narrative perspective, it could’ve been better, but I’m going to forgive them this time because this is literally based on their recollection of what happened. Garland had said he stepped back a little directorially to give Mendoza the chance to tell his story, while Mendoza successfully resisted the temptation to make himself the hero. No politics, just survival. I understand this could be triggering for some people, but I still would implore you to go support this unique experience on a big screen with big sound. Remember, there are no winners in WARFARE.
